Description.val:
The MQ-8 Fire Scout Unmanned Air System (popular name "Fire Scout") provides real-time and non-real-time Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance data to tactical users without the use of manned aircraft or reliance on limited joint theater or national assets. This line item funds improvements via engineering change orders, correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety.  This includes items such as modernization, modification of payloads/mission systems/Mission Control System (MCS) (also referred to as Ground Control Station (GCS)), and retrofit of systems/avionics.  Current inventory is 24 MQ-8B air vehicles.  The program will procure a total of 70 air vehicles (30 MQ-8B and 40 MQ-8Cs) to support Fleet requirements.  This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) aligns to the MQ-8 Initial Operational Capability in 2014. 

The MQ-8 Fire Scout system is comprised of air vehicles, payloads (electro-optical/infra-red/laser designator-range finder, AIS, communications relay, radar, weapons and other special payloads), MCS (with Tactical Control System and Tactical Common Data Link integrated for interoperability), UAV Common Automatic Recovery System (UCARS) for automatic take-off and landings, and associated spares and support equipment.

Justification.val: This line item funds improvements via engineering change orders, correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety. This includes correction of deficiencies found during operational use and deployments, improvements for maintainability and reliability, safety corrections, radar/weapons/other special payloads, Mission Control Station, emerging requirements, and concurrency in MQ-8 development and production.

ModificationTitle.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiences and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Name.@footnote: Due to the number of ECPs starting and stopping between FY16 to FY20, the Support cost elements (ILS, Data, Training Equipment, Support Equipment, and Other Support) cannot be analyzed at a level inflation rate.

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) will improve capability to improve system performance, reliability and maintainability of sensors, avionics and airframe components, and provide improved sensors for Intelligence, Surveillance, & Reconnaissance (ISR) collection for both Navy and urgent operational requirements. Some modifications will be Depot Level, performed at Fleet Readiness Centers (FRCs). These modifications include radar, weapons, navigator system, and vibration monitoring system upgrades.   

This OSIP will also correct deficiencies resulting from safety, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS). These components include, but are not limited to, the Vehicle Management Computer, Payloads Interface Unit, the Mission Control Station (MCS), ARC-210 Radios, and network interfaces.

This OSIP will also support Payload modifications which will be Depot level, performed at FRCs. Structural and wiring modifications for mounting and wiring provisions of additional payloads. Installation of the payloads themselves would be done at the O-level based on mission requirements. 

This OSIP supports MQ-8B, MQ-8C aircraft systems, MCS, UAV Common Automated Recovery System, Tactical Control Data Link, and payloads. Aircraft will be modified in FY16 to support obsolescence/reliability corrections, radar/weapons/other payloads, and airframe reliability. PB-16 provides additional fidelity of Obsolescence/Reliability improvements.

The MQ-8B based system had an approved Milestone C (MS C) in May 2007.  In 2014 MQ-8 completed the Nunn-McCurdy certification process which revoked the Milestone C approval.  MS C is currently scheduled in the 2QFY16 using an MQ-8C based Fire Scout system.  MQ-8B airframes will sunset through attrition.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 
MQ-8 Initial Operational Capability occurred in FY14.  Ongoing MQ-8B deployments have occurred since FY10 to support the ISR Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need, and Urgent Operational Need requirements.  The first MQ-8C is available for tasking in FY16.
